result.title: Week 4
result.content:
Im sorry, im late. I hope everyone is doing well on their exams.

First of all, we solved problems from last week's contest so make sure you have those solved.

The week 4 contest contains some problems that need arrays, questions C and D. They are not required to be solved. I will be explaining arrays next day inshallah.

While Loops

We first talked about while loops and how they continue to loop until the condition is false (0).

We discussed how you can use while loops to output each digit of a number, the code is here: http://ideone.com/5xJqVs

We also discussed how you can use a while loop to convert a decimal number to its binary representation, which is needed in question A in week 4. Here is the code: http://ideone.com/4RwYYn

Binary Search

We also learned how to look for a number using binary search. Binary search is the process of narrowing the range we are searching in by checking its midpoint.

If the number we are looking for is bigger than the midpoint, the new left of our range is the midpoint. Since we dont need to look at anything less than the midpoint.

If the number we are looking for is less than the midpoint, the new right of our range is the midpoint. Since we dont need to look at anything greater than the midpoint.

Here is a little game you can play to understand the concept: https://www.cs.usfca.edu/~galles/visualization/Search.html

Here is just a brief outline of the code we wrote, but it depends on the question you are asked: http://ideone.com/d3OFlq

D. Forming Teams (B)

Forming Teams (A) is like a warm up for the binary search question. Do solve it first.

Like for example the last problem we solved was a minimization problem. We did a binary search on the number of people that are unsatisfied, and we want to minimize this.

Our left is zero, the minimum number of people unsatisfied. The right is m, which is the number of people who want to sit individually. All the unsatisfied people come from them, so maximum amount is their number.

Let 'un' represent the number of people unsatisfied. We want to check if this is a valid answer. If there is un people unsatisfied, then there is m â€” un people satisfied. Each of these satisfied people get a computer to themselves. So we decrease from 'k' ( the number of computers) the number of people satisfied.

We are now left with 'c' computers. We need to fit all the people 'n' and the unsatisfied 'un' into these k computers. It is best to put them into groups of three to see if they fit.

Let 'g' be the number of computers needed to seat the remainder. If it is less than the number of computers left 'c', then they can all be seated with 'un' unsatisfied students. Since we know 'un' is a valid answer and we want to minimize our answer, we wont look at anything larger than 'un' unsatisfied students. Therefore our new right for our binary search is mid-1.

If we cannot seat them all comfortably, then more people have to be unsatisfied for them to all be seated. Therefore we dont look at anything less than 'un' since we know it wont work either, and our new left is now 'un' (or mid).

Here is the code we wrote for it: http://ideone.com/SQfl2I
